title: Facial attractiveness of cleft patients: a direct comparison between artificial-intelligence-based scoring and conventional rater groups
author: Patcas, Raphael and Timofte, Radu and Volokitin, Anna and Agustsson, Eirikur and Eliades, Theodore and Eichenberger, Martina and Bornstein, Michael Marc
abstract: Abstract  Objective: To compare facial attractiveness (FA) ratings of cleft patients by artificial intelligence (AI) and conventional rater groups.  Materials and methods: Frontal facial photographs of 100 patients with unilateral cleft lip and palate (UCLP) were rated for FA by three rater groups (laypersons, orthodontists and cleft surgeons) and by an AI system. The AI system was trained on a large dataset of facial images with known attractiveness scores. Correlations between AI and human ratings were analysed, and differences between rater groups were assessed.  Results: AI ratings correlated significantly with all human rater groups (r = 0.45–0.58, P < 0.001). The highest correlation was found between AI and laypersons (r = 0.58). Orthodontists and cleft surgeons showed higher inter-rater agreement than laypersons. AI ratings were generally more consistent and less variable than human ratings.  Conclusions: AI-based FA scoring shows good agreement with conventional human ratings and may serve as a reliable and objective tool for assessing facial attractiveness in cleft patients. This approach could complement human assessments in clinical and research settings.

title: Turning subjective into objective: the BCCT. core software for evaluation of cosmetic results in breast cancer conservative treatment
author: Cardoso, Maria Joao and Cardoso, Jaime and Amaral, Nat{\'a}lia and Azevedo, Isabel and Barreau, Lise and Bernardo, Mario and Christie, David and Costa, Susy and Fitzal, Florian and Fougo, Jos{\'e} L and others
abstract: Background: The evaluation of cosmetic results after breast cancer conservative treatment (BCCT) is usually based on subjective scores. The BCCT.core software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of cosmetic results. Methods: The BCCT.core software analyses digital photographs of the breasts and calculates objective parameters such as breast retraction assessment, lower breast contour, and color differences. These parameters are combined to provide an overall cosmetic score. Results: The software was tested on a series of patients and showed good correlation with subjective evaluations by experts. It provides a standardized and reproducible method for cosmetic assessment. Conclusion: The BCCT.core software represents a valuable tool for objective evaluation of cosmetic outcomes after breast cancer conservative treatment, facilitating comparison between studies and improving clinical decision-making.

title: Aesthetic, quality-of-life, and clinical outcomes after inferior pedicle oncoplastic reduction mammoplasty
author: Xia, Thomas Y and Scomacao, Isis and Duraes, Eliana and Cakmakoglu, Cagri and Schwarz, Graham
abstract: Purpose Oncoplastic reduction mammoplasty (ORM) is a surgical technique that combines oncologic resection with breast reduction and mastopexy techniques to improve aesthetic and quality-of-life (QoL) outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate aesthetic, QoL, and clinical outcomes after inferior pedicle ORM. Methods A retrospective review was conducted of patients who underwent inferior pedicle ORM for breast cancer between 2010 and 2020. Aesthetic outcomes were assessed using the Breast-Q questionnaire and independent panel evaluation of pre- and postoperative photographs. QoL was measured using the Breast-Q and the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30). Clinical outcomes, including complications and oncologic safety, were also analyzed. Results Forty-five patients met inclusion criteria. The median follow-up was 36 months. Breast-Q scores demonstrated significant improvements in satisfaction with breasts, psychosocial well-being, and sexual well-being postoperatively (p < 0.05). Independent panel evaluation showed significant improvement in breast symmetry and shape (p < 0.01). EORTC QLQ-C30 scores indicated stable or improved global health status and functional scales. Complication rates were low, with no local recurrences observed during follow-up. Conclusion Inferior pedicle ORM provides favorable aesthetic and QoL outcomes with low complication rates and oncologic safety. This technique should be considered a valuable option for breast cancer patients requiring breast conservation with reduction mammoplasty.

title: Assessing patient-reported outcomes following orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty
author: Schwitzer, Jonathan A and Albino, Frank P and Mathis, Ryan K and Scott, Amie M and Gamble, Laurie and Baker, Stephen B
abstract: Background: Orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty are commonly performed to correct dentofacial deformities and improve facial aesthetics and function. Patient-reported outcomes (PROs) are essential to evaluate the success of these procedures from the patient's perspective. This study aimed to assess PROs following orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty using validated questionnaires.  Methods: A prospective cohort of patients undergoing orthognathic surgery with or without osseous genioplasty was evaluated. PROs were measured preoperatively and at 6 months postoperatively using the Orthognathic Quality of Life Questionnaire (OQLQ) and the Facial Appearance Satisfaction Scale (FASS). Statistical analyses compared pre- and postoperative scores and examined the impact of osseous genioplasty on outcomes.  Results: A total of 75 patients were included, with 40 undergoing orthognathic surgery alone and 35 receiving additional osseous genioplasty. Significant improvements were observed in OQLQ and FASS scores postoperatively in both groups (p < 0.001). Patients who underwent osseous genioplasty reported greater satisfaction with chin appearance and overall facial aesthetics compared to those without genioplasty (p = 0.02). Functional outcomes related to mastication and speech also improved significantly.  Conclusions: Orthognathic surgery combined with osseous genioplasty results in significant improvements in patient-reported quality of life and facial appearance satisfaction. Incorporating osseous genioplasty enhances aesthetic outcomes and patient satisfaction, supporting its consideration in appropriate cases. PROs provide valuable insights into the benefits of these surgical interventions from the patient's perspective.

title: Evaluation of the effects of silk and polyethylene terephthalate sutures on postoperative complications in impacted lower third molar surgery
author: Dilan O.Z.; Levent C.; Volkan K.; Mehmet G.; Abdurrahman G.; Mohammad A.; Anıl Ö.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of silk and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) sutures on postoperative complications in impacted lower third molar surgery. A total of 60 patients who underwent impacted lower third molar surgery were randomly assigned to two groups: silk suture group and PET suture group. Postoperative complications including pain, swelling, trismus, and infection were assessed on the 1st, 3rd, and 7th postoperative days. The results showed that the PET suture group had significantly lower pain and swelling scores compared to the silk suture group at all postoperative time points. Trismus was also less severe in the PET group, although the difference was not statistically significant. No infections were observed in either group. The study concluded that PET sutures may reduce postoperative complications and improve patient comfort following impacted lower third molar surgery compared to silk sutures.

title: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models
author: Ho, Jonathan and Jain, Ajay and Abbeel, Pieter
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems
abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) are a class of latent variable models inspired by non-equilibrium thermodynamics, which have recently been shown to generate high-quality images. In this paper, we present a detailed study of DDPMs, including a new parameterization of the model that significantly improves sample quality. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the model's training objective and sampling procedure, showing that the model can be interpreted as a variational autoencoder with a particular choice of approximate posterior. Our experiments demonstrate that DDPMs achieve state-of-the-art results on several image generation benchmarks, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet, and produce samples with high fidelity and diversity.

author: Zhao X.; Li M.; Li M.; Li W.; Li A.; Cheng Y.; Pei D.
abstract: Periodontal dressing is widely used in periodontal surgery to protect the wound and promote healing. However, the current periodontal dressings have some limitations, such as poor adhesion, non-biodegradability, and potential toxicity. Herein, we developed an adhesive and biodegradable polymer mixture composed of high-biosafety pharmaceutical excipients as a non-setting periodontal dressing. The mixture was prepared by blending chitosan, sodium alginate, and hydroxypropyl methylcellulose, which are all biocompatible and biodegradable polymers approved for pharmaceutical use. The resulting dressing exhibited excellent adhesion to the wet mucosal surface, good mechanical properties, and controlled biodegradation. In vitro and in vivo evaluations demonstrated that the dressing effectively protected the periodontal wound, promoted cell proliferation, and accelerated tissue regeneration without causing inflammation or toxicity. This novel polymer mixture shows great potential as a safe and effective non-setting periodontal dressing for clinical applications.

title: Multiscale mechano-biological finite element modelling of oncoplastic breast surgery—numerical study towards surgical planning and cosmetic outcome prediction
author: Vavourakis, Vasileios and Eiben, Bjoern and Hipwell, John H and Williams, Norman R and Keshtgar, Mo and Hawkes, David J
doi: Public Library of Science San Francisco, CA USA
abstract: Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) is the standard treatment for early-stage breast cancer. Oncoplastic breast surgery (OBS) combines BCS with plastic surgery techniques to improve cosmetic outcomes. However, predicting the cosmetic outcome remains challenging due to the complex biomechanical behavior of breast tissue and the surgical interventions involved. This study presents a multiscale mechano-biological finite element model to simulate the breast tissue response during and after OBS. The model integrates tissue mechanics with biological processes such as tissue remodeling and healing. Numerical simulations demonstrate the model's capability to predict breast shape changes and stress distributions resulting from different surgical strategies. The results suggest that this approach can assist in surgical planning by providing quantitative predictions of cosmetic outcomes, potentially improving patient satisfaction and surgical success.

title: BCCT. core--Can a computer program be used for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery?
author: Preuss, James and Lester, L and Saunders, Christobel
abstract: Background: The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of aesthetic outcome after breast conserving treatment. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of BCCT.core for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery.  Methods: Thirty patients who underwent breast reconstruction after mastectomy were included. Standardized photographs were taken and evaluated by BCCT.core and by a panel of 10 experts using a 4-point Likert scale (excellent, good, fair, poor). Agreement between BCCT.core and the panel was assessed using weighted kappa statistics.  Results: BCCT.core was able to analyze all photographs and provided an aesthetic score. The agreement between BCCT.core and the expert panel was moderate (weighted kappa = 0.52). BCCT.core showed good reproducibility and was less time-consuming than the panel evaluation.  Conclusions: BCCT.core is a feasible tool for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery. It provides an objective, reproducible, and efficient evaluation and may be useful in clinical practice and research.

title: Patient specific finite element model of the face soft tissues for computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery
author: Chabanas, Matthieu and Luboz, Vincent and Payan, Yohan
abstract: This paper presents a method to build patient specific finite element models of the face soft tissues to be used in computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery. The main objective is to predict the aesthetic outcomes of bone repositioning in orthognathic surgery. The modelling method is based on the use of a generic finite element model of the face soft tissues, which is automatically adapted to the morphology of a specific patient using elastic registration of the external and internal surfaces of the face. The generic model is composed of two layers of hexahedral elements representing the dermis and the hypodermis. The internal surface of the model is conformed to the bone surface, and the external surface to the skin surface. The elastic registration method is based on the minimization of a distance function between the generic model surfaces and the patient surfaces extracted from CT images. The method is applied to a clinical case and the results are presented. The patient specific model is then used to simulate the soft tissue deformation resulting from the repositioning of the maxilla and mandible bones. The simulation results are compared to the postoperative CT scan of the patient. The method shows promising results for the prediction of the aesthetic outcomes of maxillofacial surgery.

author: Haque, Ayaan and Tancik, Matthew and Efros, Alexei A and Holynski, Aleksander and Kanazawa, Angjoo
abstract: Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) have shown great success in modeling 3D scenes, but editing these scenes remains a challenging problem. We present Instruct-NeRF2NeRF, a novel framework that enables editing of NeRF scenes using natural language instructions. Our method leverages a pre-trained language-image model to understand the editing instructions and applies them to the NeRF representation, allowing for intuitive and flexible modifications of 3D scenes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on various editing tasks, including object addition, removal, and attribute modification, achieving high-quality results that align with the given instructions. Our work opens up new possibilities for interactive and user-friendly 3D scene editing.

author: Nicklaus, Krista M and Cheong, Audrey and Sampathkumar, Urmila and Liu, Jun and Chopra, Deepti and Hoffman, Aubri and Merchant, Fatima A and Hanson, Summer E and Markey, Mia K and Reece, Gregory P
abstract: Background: Breast reconstruction after mastectomy is a complex decision-making process influenced by various factors, including patient preferences and expected aesthetic outcomes. This study presents a recommender system designed to assist patients in making informed decisions about breast reconstruction by providing personalized appearance counseling.  Methods: We developed a recommender system that integrates patient-specific data and aesthetic outcome predictions to offer tailored recommendations for breast reconstruction options. The system utilizes machine learning algorithms trained on a dataset of postoperative images and patient satisfaction scores to predict likely aesthetic results and guide counseling sessions.  Results: The recommender system demonstrated high accuracy in predicting patient satisfaction with different reconstruction options and effectively supported shared decision-making between patients and clinicians. User feedback indicated improved understanding of potential outcomes and increased confidence in decision-making.  Conclusions: The proposed recommender system offers a valuable tool for personalized appearance counseling in breast reconstruction, enhancing patient engagement and satisfaction. Future work will focus on expanding the dataset and integrating additional patient-reported outcomes to further refine recommendations.

title: Development of novel artificial intelligence systems to predict facial morphology after orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment in Japanese patients
author: Tanikawa, Chihiro and Yamashiro, Takashi
abstract: Accurate prediction of facial morphology after orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment is important for treatment planning and patient communication. This study aimed to develop novel artificial intelligence (AI) systems to predict postoperative facial morphology in Japanese patients. We collected pre- and postoperative three-dimensional facial images and cephalometric data from 100 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment. Using these data, we trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict postoperative facial morphology from preoperative images and cephalometric measurements. The AI systems demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative facial morphology, with mean errors within clinically acceptable ranges. These findings suggest that AI-based prediction models can be valuable tools for clinicians in planning orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment, enhancing patient communication and treatment outcomes.

title: Watching the Vessels Grow: Establishment of Intravital Microscopy in the Arteriovenous Loop Rat Model
author: Hessenauer M.; Vaghela R.; Körner C.; Von Hörsten S.; Pobel C.; Gage D.; Müller C.; Salehi S.; Horch R.E.; Arkudas A.
abstract: The arteriovenous (AV) loop model is a well-established in vivo model for the generation of axially vascularized tissue constructs. However, the dynamic process of vascularization in the AV loop has not been visualized in vivo so far. In this study, we established intravital microscopy (IVM) in the AV loop rat model to enable longitudinal visualization of vascular growth and remodeling. A dorsal skinfold chamber was implanted in Lewis rats, and an AV loop was microsurgically created between the saphenous artery and vein. The AV loop was embedded in a fibrin matrix and placed into the chamber. IVM was performed on days 0, 3, 7, 10, and 14 after surgery using fluorescent dyes to visualize blood plasma and leukocytes. The AV loop remained patent throughout the observation period. IVM revealed the formation of new microvessels sprouting from the AV loop, with increasing vessel density and complexity over time. Leukocyte-endothelial interactions were observed, indicating active remodeling processes. This study demonstrates the feasibility of IVM in the AV loop rat model, providing a powerful tool to study vascularization dynamics in vivo and to evaluate therapeutic strategies for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

title: FBPFormer: Dynamic convolutional transformer for global-local-contexual facial beauty prediction
author: Liu, Qipeng and Lin, Luojun and Shen, Zhifeng and Yu, Yuanlong
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) aims to automatically assess the attractiveness of a given face image, which is a challenging task due to the complex and subjective nature of human perception of beauty. Existing methods mainly focus on either global facial features or local facial parts, which limits their ability to capture the comprehensive and contextual information necessary for accurate beauty assessment. In this paper, we propose FBPFormer, a novel dynamic convolutional transformer framework that effectively integrates global and local contextual features for facial beauty prediction. Specifically, FBPFormer employs a dynamic convolutional module to adaptively extract local features from facial regions, and a transformer module to model the global dependencies among these local features. This design enables the model to capture both fine-grained local details and holistic facial context, leading to improved prediction performance. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that FBPFormer outperforms state-of-the-art methods, validating the effectiveness of our approach in capturing global-local contextual information for facial beauty prediction.

title: Histologic Evaluation of the Effects of Folinic Acid Chitosan Hydrogel and Botulinum Toxin A on Wound Repair of Cleft Lip Surgery in Rats
author: Namdar P.; Moaddabi A.; Yazdian R.; Saeedi M.; Ahmadian F.; Shiva A.; Del Giudice C.; Soltani P.; Spagnuolo G.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of folinic acid chitosan hydrogel and botulinum toxin A (BTX-A) on wound repair of cleft lip surgery in rats. Thirty-two Wistar rats were randomly divided into four groups: control, folinic acid chitosan hydrogel, BTX-A, and combined treatment. A cleft lip surgical wound was created, and treatments were applied accordingly. Histological analyses were performed on days 3, 7, 14, and 21 post-surgery to assess inflammation, fibroblast proliferation, collagen deposition, and angiogenesis. The folinic acid chitosan hydrogel group showed enhanced fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition compared to control. BTX-A treatment reduced inflammation and improved angiogenesis. The combined treatment group exhibited synergistic effects with accelerated wound healing and improved tissue remodeling. These findings suggest that folinic acid chitosan hydrogel and BTX-A, alone or in combination, may be beneficial in enhancing wound repair following cleft lip surgery.

title: The use of the FACE-Q aesthetic: a narrative review
author: Ottenhof, Maarten J and Veldhuizen, Inge J and Hensbergen, Lusanne J v and Blankensteijn, Louise L and Bramer, Wichor and Lei, Berend vd and Hoogbergen, Maarten M and Hulst, Ren{\'e} RWJ and Sidey-Gibbons, Chris J
abstract: Purpose The FACE-Q Aesthetic is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) designed to evaluate outcomes in aesthetic facial procedures. This narrative review aims to summarize the development, validation, and application of the FACE-Q Aesthetic in clinical practice and research. Methods A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify studies utilizing the FACE-Q Aesthetic. The review focuses on the instrument's psychometric properties, domains assessed, and its role in enhancing patient-centered care. Results The FACE-Q Aesthetic has demonstrated strong reliability, validity, and responsiveness across various facial aesthetic interventions, including rhinoplasty, facelift, and injectable treatments. Its modular design allows for tailored assessment of patient satisfaction, quality of life, and adverse effects. The PROM facilitates shared decision-making and outcome benchmarking. Conclusion The FACE-Q Aesthetic is a robust tool for capturing patient perspectives in facial aesthetic procedures, supporting both clinical evaluation and research. Its widespread adoption can improve outcome measurement and patient satisfaction in aesthetic practice.

title: Breast retraction assessment: an objective evaluation of cosmetic results of patients treated conservatively for breast cancer
author: Pezner, Richard D and Patterson, Mary P and Hill, L Robert and Vora, Nayana and Desai, Kanta R and Archambeau, John O and Lipsett, James A
journal: International Journal of Radiation Oncology* Biology* Physics
abstract: Breast retraction assessment (BRA) is a new method for the objective evaluation of cosmetic results after conservative treatment of breast cancer. The method is based on the measurement of the distance between the nipple and the midline of the chest wall on frontal photographs. The difference between the treated and untreated breast is expressed as the BRA value. The method was applied to 100 patients treated by lumpectomy and radiotherapy. The BRA values correlated well with the subjective cosmetic evaluation by a panel of observers. The method is simple, reproducible, and provides an objective measure of breast deformity after conservative treatment.

title: Applying artificial intelligence to assess the impact of orthognathic treatment on facial attractiveness and estimated age
author: Patcas, Raphael and Bernini, Domino AJ and Volokitin, Anna and Agustsson, Eirikur and Rothe, Rasmus and Timofte, Radu
journal: International journal of oral and maxillofacial surgery
abstract: The aim of this study was to apply artificial intelligence (AI) to assess the impact of orthognathic treatment on facial attractiveness and estimated age. Pre- and post-treatment facial photographs of 46 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery were analysed using a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained to estimate facial attractiveness and age. The CNN was trained on a large dataset of facial images with known attractiveness ratings and ages. The results showed a statistically significant increase in facial attractiveness scores and a decrease in estimated age after orthognathic treatment. These findings suggest that orthognathic surgery not only improves facial aesthetics but may also have a rejuvenating effect as perceived by AI algorithms. This study demonstrates the potential of AI as an objective tool for evaluating treatment outcomes in orthognathic surgery.

title: A computational approach to relative aesthetics
author: Gattupalli, Vijetha and Chandakkar, Parag S and Li, Baoxin
abstract: Aesthetics is a subjective concept and it is difficult to design a computational model which can measure the aesthetic quality of an image. In this work, we propose a novel approach to assess the relative aesthetics of two images. Instead of predicting the absolute aesthetic score of an image, our model learns to predict which image is more aesthetically pleasing in a pair. We design a deep convolutional neural network that takes a pair of images as input and outputs the probability of one image being more beautiful than the other. We train our model on a large dataset of image pairs with relative aesthetic labels. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods on the task of relative aesthetics prediction.

title: Feasibility of anomaly score detected with deep learning in irradiated breast cancer patients with reconstruction
author: Kim, Dong-Yun and Lee, Soo Jin and Kim, Eun-Kyu and Kang, Eunyoung and Heo, Chan Yeong and Jeong, Jae Hoon and Myung, Yujin and Kim, In Ah and Jang, Bum-Sup
abstract: Radiation therapy (RT) is a critical component of breast cancer treatment, but it can cause complications in patients who undergo breast reconstruction. Early detection of these complications is essential for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. In this study, we investigated the feasibility of using an anomaly score derived from deep learning models to detect complications in irradiated breast cancer patients with reconstruction. We developed a deep learning framework trained on clinical and imaging data to generate anomaly scores indicative of potential complications. Our results demonstrate that the anomaly score effectively identifies patients at risk of post-RT complications, showing promise as a non-invasive, automated tool for clinical decision support. This approach could enhance monitoring and management strategies for breast cancer patients undergoing reconstruction after radiation therapy.

title: Unpaired image-to-image translation using cycle-consistent adversarial networks
author: Zhu, Jun-Yan and Park, Taesung and Isola, Phillip and Efros, Alexei A
abstract: Unpaired image-to-image translation is the problem of learning to translate an image from a source domain X to a target domain Y in the absence of paired examples. We present an approach for learning to translate an image from a source domain X to a target domain Y in the absence of paired examples. Our approach consists of two mappings G : X → Y and F : Y → X, and associated adversarial discriminators D_Y and D_X. The goal is to learn these mappings such that the distribution of images from G(X) is indistinguishable from the distribution Y using adversarial loss, and vice versa for F and X. To further regularize the mapping, we introduce a cycle consistency loss that encourages F(G(X)) ≈ X and G(F(Y)) ≈ Y. Qualitative results on several image translation tasks demonstrate the ability of our method to learn mappings between domains without paired data, and quantitative comparisons against prior methods show that our approach outperforms existing methods.

title: A novel noncontact high-resolution charge density mapping system to guide ablation of complex atrial arrhythmias: overview of device technology and application
author: Bala G.; De Asmundis C.; Chierchia G.-B.
abstract: Atrial arrhythmias are a common cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Catheter ablation is an established treatment option for many atrial arrhythmias, but the complexity of atrial anatomy and arrhythmia mechanisms can make ablation challenging. Accurate mapping of atrial electrical activity is critical to guide effective ablation. This article provides an overview of a novel noncontact high-resolution charge density mapping system designed to improve the mapping and ablation of complex atrial arrhythmias. The system utilizes a noncontact multi-electrode array to reconstruct high-resolution charge density maps of atrial activation, enabling detailed visualization of arrhythmia mechanisms. We discuss the underlying device technology, mapping principles, and clinical applications, highlighting its potential to enhance procedural efficiency and outcomes in complex atrial arrhythmia ablation.

title: Utilization of machine learning for the objective assessment of rhinoplasty outcomes
author: Topsakal, Oguzhan and Dobratz, Eric J and Akbas, Mustafa Ilhan and Dougherty, William M and Akinci, Tahir Cetin and Celikoyar, Mehmet Mazhar

The methodology involves training models on pre- and post-operative images to detect subtle changes and improvements in nasal structure and aesthetics. Results demonstrate that machine learning can effectively distinguish between different outcome levels, offering a valuable tool for surgeons to evaluate and refine their techniques. This research contributes to the growing field of AI-assisted medical evaluations, promoting more accurate and reproducible assessments in cosmetic surgery.

title: Mitral valve flattening and parameter mapping for patient-specific valve diagnosis
author: Lichtenberg N.; Eulzer P.; Romano G.; Brčić A.; Karck M.; Lawonn K.; De Simone R.; Engelhardt S.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Mitral valve (MV) disease is a common heart valve disease that can lead to heart failure. Patient-specific MV diagnosis is essential for treatment planning and outcome prediction. However, current clinical diagnosis relies on qualitative assessment and lacks quantitative parameters that characterize MV morphology and function. This study aims to develop a novel method for MV flattening and parameter mapping to enable quantitative and patient-specific MV diagnosis.  Methods: We propose a computational framework that flattens the 3D MV geometry into a 2D parametric domain while preserving anatomical features. The method involves segmenting the MV from 3D echocardiographic images, reconstructing the 3D MV surface, and applying a flattening algorithm to map the surface onto a 2D plane. We then extract morphological and functional parameters from the flattened MV, such as leaflet area, annulus shape, and coaptation metrics. The framework is validated on synthetic and clinical datasets.  Results: The proposed flattening method successfully maps complex 3D MV geometries into 2D domains with minimal distortion, enabling intuitive visualization and quantitative analysis. Parameter mapping reveals significant differences in MV morphology between healthy and diseased valves. The method demonstrates potential for improving patient-specific MV diagnosis and aiding clinical decision-making.  Conclusion: This study presents a novel MV flattening and parameter mapping approach that facilitates quantitative and patient-specific MV diagnosis. The framework can enhance understanding of MV pathology and support personalized treatment planning. Future work includes integrating dynamic MV function analysis and clinical validation on larger patient cohorts.

title: Time-dependent bladder tissue regeneration using bilayer bladder acellular matrix graft-silk fibroin scaffolds in a rat bladder augmentation model
author: Zhao Y.; He Y.; Guo J.-H.; Wu J.-S.; Zhou Z.; Zhang M.; Li W.; Zhou J.; Xiao D.-D.; Wang Z.; Sun K.; Zhu Y.-J.; Lu M.-J.
abstract: Bladder acellular matrix graft (BAMG) has been widely used in bladder tissue engineering, but its poor mechanical properties and rapid degradation limit its application. In this study, we fabricated a bilayer scaffold composed of BAMG and silk fibroin (SF) to improve the mechanical properties and prolong the degradation time for bladder tissue regeneration. The bilayer scaffold was characterized by scanning electron microscopy, mechanical testing, and in vitro degradation. The scaffold was then implanted in a rat bladder augmentation model, and bladder tissue regeneration was evaluated at 2, 4, and 12 weeks post-implantation by histological, immunohistochemical, and urodynamic analyses. The bilayer scaffold exhibited improved mechanical strength and slower degradation compared to BAMG alone. Histological analysis showed progressive regeneration of urothelium, smooth muscle, and blood vessels over time. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of contractile smooth muscle markers and endothelial markers in the regenerated tissue. Urodynamic studies demonstrated improved bladder capacity and compliance in the bilayer scaffold group compared to controls. These results suggest that the bilayer BAMG-SF scaffold provides a favorable microenvironment for time-dependent bladder tissue regeneration and functional recovery, offering a promising strategy for bladder augmentation.

title: A novel artificial intelligence model for symmetry evaluation in breast cancer patients
author: Kenig, Nitzan and Monton Echeverria, Javier and Chang Azancot, Luis and De la Ossa, Luis
abstract: Breast symmetry is an important factor in the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer patients after surgery. Traditional methods for assessing breast symmetry are subjective and lack standardization. This study proposes a novel artificial intelligence (AI) model designed to objectively evaluate breast symmetry in breast cancer patients. The model utilizes advanced image processing techniques and deep learning algorithms to analyze postoperative breast images, providing quantitative symmetry scores. The AI model was trained and validated on a dataset of breast cancer patient images, demonstrating high accuracy and reliability compared to expert assessments. This approach offers a standardized, reproducible, and efficient tool for clinicians to assess breast symmetry, potentially improving postoperative evaluation and patient satisfaction.

title: The PRISMA 2020 statement: an updated guideline for reporting systematic reviews
author: Page, Matthew J and McKenzie, Joanne E and Bossuyt, Patrick M and Boutron, Isabelle and Hoffmann, Tammy C and Mulrow, Cynthia D and Shamseer, Larissa and Tetzlaff, Jennifer M and Akl, Elie A and Brennan, Sue E and others
abstract: Systematic reviews are essential for summarizing evidence to inform healthcare decisions. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement, published in 2009, is a widely used reporting guideline for systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Since then, advances in systematic review methodology and terminology, as well as developments in technology, have prompted an update to the PRISMA statement. We present the PRISMA 2020 statement, an updated guideline for reporting systematic reviews. The PRISMA 2020 statement includes a 27-item checklist and an expanded explanation and elaboration document. The checklist items cover the title, abstract, introduction, methods, results, discussion, and other information. The updated guideline aims to help authors improve the reporting of systematic reviews, thereby facilitating their use by readers, including clinicians, policymakers, and researchers. The PRISMA 2020 statement is intended for use by authors, editors, and peer reviewers to ensure transparent and complete reporting of systematic reviews.

title: Evolution, current challenges, and future possibilities in the objective assessment of aesthetic outcome of breast cancer locoregional treatment
author: Cardoso, Jaime S and Silva, Wilson and Cardoso, Maria J
abstract: Aesthetic outcome assessment after breast cancer locoregional treatment is an important aspect of patient care and research. Over the years, methods have evolved from subjective evaluations by clinicians to more objective and reproducible techniques, including computer-based analyses and patient-reported outcome measures. Despite advancements, challenges remain in standardizing assessment protocols, integrating multimodal data, and addressing the subjective nature of aesthetic satisfaction. Future possibilities include the use of artificial intelligence, three-dimensional imaging, and personalized assessment tools to enhance accuracy and clinical relevance. This review discusses the evolution, current challenges, and future directions in the objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes following breast cancer locoregional treatment.

title: Maxillofacial bone movements-aware dual graph convolution approach for postoperative facial appearance prediction
author: Xinrui Huang and Dongming He and Zhenming Li and Xiaofan Zhang and Xudong Wang
abstract: Accurate prediction of postoperative facial appearance is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication in maxillofacial surgery. Existing methods often overlook the complex anatomical and biomechanical relationships between facial bones and soft tissues, leading to suboptimal prediction accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel maxillofacial bone movements-aware dual graph convolutional network (DGCN) approach that explicitly models the interactions between bone movements and soft tissue deformations. Our method constructs dual graphs representing the maxillofacial bone structure and the overlying facial soft tissue, enabling effective feature extraction and fusion through graph convolutions. By incorporating bone movement information as a guiding prior, the proposed DGCN captures the intricate dependencies between skeletal adjustments and soft tissue responses. Extensive experiments on a clinical dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in predicting postoperative facial appearance, achieving higher accuracy and better preservation of facial identity. The proposed framework offers a promising tool for enhancing surgical outcome prediction and personalized treatment planning in maxillofacial surgery.

title: Artificial intelligence for rhinoplasty design in Asian patients
author: Li, Ruoyu and Shu, Fan and Zhen, Yonghuan and Song, Zhexiang and An, Yang and Jiang, Yin
abstract: Purpose Rhinoplasty is a challenging procedure, especially in Asian patients, due to the unique anatomical features and aesthetic preferences. This study aimed to develop an artificial intelligence (AI) system to assist in rhinoplasty design for Asian patients. Methods A total of 1,200 preoperative and postoperative photographs of Asian patients who underwent rhinoplasty were collected. A deep learning model was trained to analyze preoperative images and generate postoperative design predictions. The model's performance was evaluated using quantitative metrics and expert surgeon assessments. Results The AI system demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative nasal shapes, with a mean structural similarity index measure (SSIM) of 0.87 compared to actual postoperative images. Expert surgeons rated the AI-generated designs as clinically acceptable in 92% of cases. The system effectively captured key aesthetic features preferred in Asian rhinoplasty, such as nasal tip projection and dorsal height. Conclusion The developed AI model shows promise as a tool for preoperative planning and patient consultation in Asian rhinoplasty, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient satisfaction. Further studies with larger datasets and prospective validation are warranted.

title: Objective measurement of cosmetic outcomes of breast conserving therapy using BCCT. core
author: Yu, Tosol and Eom, Keun-Yong and Jang, Na Young and Kim, Kyung Su and Koo, Tae Ryool and Kwon, Jeanny and Kim, Byoung Hyuck and Kang, Eunyoung and Kim, Sung-Won and Kim, Jae-Sung and others
journal: Cancer Research and Treatment: Official Journal of Korean Cancer Association
abstract: Purpose: The cosmetic outcome after breast conserving therapy (BCT) is an important factor in the evaluation of treatment success. The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible assessment of cosmetic outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the cosmetic outcomes of BCT using BCCT.core and to identify factors influencing these outcomes.  Materials and Methods: A total of 190 patients who underwent BCT were enrolled. Standardized photographs were taken at least 1 year after surgery. Cosmetic outcomes were assessed using BCCT.core software, which analyzes breast symmetry, color, and scar appearance. Clinical and treatment-related factors were analyzed to determine their association with cosmetic results.  Results: The BCCT.core scores classified cosmetic outcomes as excellent in 35.3%, good in 44.7%, fair in 15.3%, and poor in 4.7% of patients. Factors significantly associated with poorer cosmetic outcomes included larger tumor size, higher radiation dose, and presence of surgical complications. Multivariate analysis identified tumor size and radiation dose as independent predictors of cosmetic results.  Conclusion: BCCT.core provides an objective and reproducible method for evaluating cosmetic outcomes after BCT. Larger tumor size and higher radiation dose negatively impact cosmetic results. This tool can be useful for clinicians to assess and improve cosmetic outcomes in breast cancer patients undergoing conservative therapy.

title: Aggregated residual transformations for deep neural networks
author: Xie, Saining and Girshick, Ross and Doll{\'a}r, Piotr and Tu, Zhuowen and He, Kaiming
abstract: Deep residual networks have emerged as a powerful architecture for image recognition. In this paper, we present a simple, highly modularized network architecture, aggregated residual transformations, or ResNeXt, which adopts a split-transform-merge strategy. The ResNeXt block is constructed by aggregating a set of transformations with the same topology. Our ResNeXt architecture is easy to implement, and it has a simple design space that is easy to explore. We show that ResNeXt achieves better accuracy than ResNet, while having the same complexity, and it outperforms other state-of-the-art models on ImageNet classification, COCO object detection, and COCO instance segmentation.

title: Correlation of prediction and actual outcome of three-dimensional simulation in breast augmentation using a cloud-based program
author: Vorstenbosch, Joshua and Islur, Avi
abstract: Purpose Three-dimensional (3D) simulation is widely used in breast augmentation surgery. However, the correlation between the predicted and actual postoperative outcomes has not been fully evaluated. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of a cloud-based 3D simulation program in predicting postoperative breast volume and shape. Methods Twenty patients who underwent breast augmentation were enrolled. Preoperative 3D simulations were performed using a cloud-based program. Postoperative 3D images were obtained 6 months after surgery. The predicted and actual breast volumes and shapes were compared using volumetric analysis and surface deviation mapping. Results The mean predicted breast volume was 350.2 ± 45.6 mL, and the actual postoperative volume was 342.8 ± 48.3 mL, showing a strong correlation (r = 0.92, p < 0.001). Surface deviation analysis revealed an average deviation of 2.3 ± 0.7 mm between predicted and actual breast shapes. Conclusion The cloud-based 3D simulation program demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative breast volume and shape in breast augmentation surgery. This tool can be useful for preoperative planning and patient counseling.

title: Systematic review of Breast-Q: a tool to evaluate post-mastectomy breast reconstruction
author: Seth, Ishith and Seth, Nimish and Bulloch, Gabriella and Rozen, Warren M and Hunter-Smith, David J
abstract: Background: Breast-Q is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) designed to evaluate outcomes in breast surgery, including post-mastectomy breast reconstruction (PMBR). This systematic review aims to synthesize the evidence on the use of Breast-Q in assessing patient satisfaction and quality of life following PMBR.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies utilizing Breast-Q for PMBR evaluation. Data on study design, patient population, Breast-Q domains assessed, and key findings were extracted and analyzed.  Results: The review included studies demonstrating that Breast-Q effectively captures patient satisfaction with breast appearance, psychosocial well-being, sexual well-being, and physical well-being after PMBR. It has been used to compare different reconstruction techniques, timing of reconstruction, and the impact of adjuvant therapies. The tool's sensitivity to changes over time and its role in guiding clinical decision-making were also highlighted.  Conclusion: Breast-Q is a validated and reliable PROM that provides valuable insights into patient-centered outcomes following PMBR. Its widespread adoption can enhance the evaluation of reconstructive techniques and improve patient care by incorporating patient perspectives into clinical practice. title: Machine learning demonstrates high accuracy for disease diagnosis and prognosis in plastic surgery
author: Mantelakis, Angelos and Assael, Yannis and Sorooshian, Parviz and Khajuria, Ankur
abstract: Machine learning (ML) is a subset of artificial intelligence that has demonstrated high accuracy in disease diagnosis and prognosis across various medical specialties. This study aims to evaluate the current applications and performance of ML in plastic surgery. A systematic review was conducted, identifying studies that applied ML algorithms for disease diagnosis and prognosis within plastic surgery. The results indicate that ML models achieve high accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity, outperforming traditional statistical methods in many cases. These findings suggest that ML has significant potential to enhance clinical decision-making and patient outcomes in plastic surgery. Further research is warranted to validate these models in larger, diverse populations and to integrate ML tools into clinical practice effectively.

title: Soft tissue prediction in orthognathic surgery: Improving accuracy by means of anatomical details
author: Ruggiero, Federica and Borghi, Alessandro and Bevini, Mirko and Badiali, Giovanni and Lunari, Ottavia and Dunaway, David and Marchetti, Claudio
doi: Public Library of Science San Francisco, CA USA
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery is essential for treatment planning and patient communication. Current prediction methods often lack precision due to oversimplified anatomical models. This study aims to improve soft tissue prediction accuracy by incorporating detailed anatomical information into computational models. Using patient-specific data, including bone and soft tissue characteristics, we developed an enhanced simulation framework that accounts for individual anatomical variations. Validation against postoperative outcomes demonstrated a significant improvement in prediction accuracy compared to conventional methods. Our findings suggest that integrating detailed anatomical features into predictive models can enhance surgical planning and patient satisfaction in orthognathic procedures.

title: Dynamic indocyanine green angiography measurements
author: Holmes T.; Invernizzi A.; Larkin S.; Staurenghi G.
abstract: Indocyanine green (ICG) angiography is a widely used technique for imaging blood flow in the retina and choroid. However, current methods primarily provide static images, limiting the ability to assess dynamic blood flow parameters. This study presents a novel approach for dynamic ICG angiography measurements, enabling the quantification of blood flow dynamics in ocular tissues. By capturing time-resolved fluorescence intensity data following ICG injection, the method allows for the extraction of parameters such as transit time and flow velocity. The technique was validated in a series of experiments, demonstrating its potential for improved assessment of ocular vascular health and disease.

title: Altered biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral control of the knee represent incomplete recovery of individuals with injury during single leg hop
author: Roos P.E.; Button K.; Sparkes V.; van Deursen R.W.M.
abstract: Altered biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral control of the knee represent incomplete recovery of individuals with injury during single leg hop  Abstract: Individuals with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury often demonstrate altered movement patterns during dynamic tasks, which may contribute to the risk of re-injury and the development of osteoarthritis. This study aimed to investigate biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral knee control during a single leg hop in individuals with ACL injury compared to healthy controls. Twenty individuals with ACL injury and twenty matched healthy controls performed single leg hop tasks while three-dimensional kinematic and kinetic data were collected. Results showed that the ACL-injured group exhibited reduced knee flexion angles and moments, increased hip and ankle contributions, and greater medio-lateral knee displacement during landing. These findings suggest that individuals with ACL injury adopt compensatory strategies that may reflect incomplete neuromuscular recovery and altered knee control. Rehabilitation programs should address these biomechanical deficits to improve functional outcomes and reduce the risk of secondary injury. title: Deep residual learning for image recognition
author: He, Kaiming and Zhang, Xiangyu and Ren, Shaoqing and Sun, Jian
abstract: Deep residual learning frameworks have recently shown excellent performance in many computer vision tasks. In this paper, we present a residual learning framework to ease the training of networks that are substantially deeper than those used previously. We explicitly reformulate the layers as learning residual functions with reference to the layer inputs, instead of learning unreferenced functions. We provide comprehensive empirical evidence showing that these residual networks are easier to optimize, and can gain accuracy from considerably increased depth. On the ImageNet dataset we evaluate residual nets with a depth of up to 152 layers—8× deeper than VGG nets but still having lower complexity. An ensemble of these residual nets achieves 3.57% error on the ImageNet test set. This result won the 1st place on the ILSVRC 2015 classification task. We also present analysis on CIFAR-10 with 100 and 1000 layers. The depth of representations is of central importance for many visual recognition tasks. Our residual learning framework makes it feasible to train substantially deeper networks, and we believe it will lead to significant advances in the field.

title: Morphing images to demonstrate potential surgical outcomes
author: Hamilton, Grant S
abstract: Morphing images to demonstrate potential surgical outcomes is a technique that can be used to help patients visualize the possible results of surgical procedures. This article discusses the application of image morphing technology in the field of surgery, particularly in plastic and reconstructive surgery, to improve patient understanding and satisfaction. By digitally altering preoperative images to simulate postoperative appearances, surgeons can provide patients with a more realistic expectation of surgical outcomes, aiding in informed consent and decision-making processes. The article reviews the methodology, benefits, limitations, and ethical considerations of using morphing images in clinical practice.

title: Vaginal tactile imaging
author: Egorov V.; Van Raalte H.; Sarvazyan A.P.
abstract: Tactile imaging is a medical imaging modality that translates the sense of touch into a digital image. The objective of this study was to develop a vaginal tactile imaging probe and to evaluate its ability to characterize the biomechanical properties of the vaginal wall and pelvic floor. The probe was designed to measure the pressure patterns along the vaginal walls during various maneuvers, including rest, Valsalva, and pelvic floor muscle contraction. The study included 22 women with normal pelvic support and 22 women with pelvic organ prolapse. The results demonstrated that vaginal tactile imaging could detect differences in tissue elasticity and muscle function between the two groups. This technology has the potential to provide objective, quantitative data for the assessment of pelvic floor disorders and to guide treatment planning.

title: Evaluation of technical feasibility and safety of Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy: Three case reports
author: Spinoglio G.; Lenti L.M.; Ravazzoni F.; Formisano G.; Pagliardi F.; Marano A.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to evaluate the technical feasibility and safety of Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy through the presentation of three case reports. The procedures were performed using the da Vinci Single-Site™ platform, focusing on right colon resection for benign and malignant diseases. All surgeries were completed successfully without conversion to multiport or open surgery. Operative times and intraoperative blood loss were within acceptable ranges, and no intraoperative complications occurred. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with patients discharged within standard time frames. These preliminary findings suggest that Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy is a feasible and safe technique, offering potential benefits in terms of reduced invasiveness and improved cosmetic outcomes. Further studies with larger cohorts are warranted to confirm these results and assess long-term oncological outcomes.

title: Mobilenets: Efficient convolutional neural networks for mobile vision applications
author: Howard, Andrew G and Zhu, Menglong and Chen, Bo and Kalenichenko, Dmitry and Wang, Weijun and Weyand, Tobias and Andreetto, Marco and Adam, Hartwig
abstract: MobileNets are a class of efficient models designed specifically for mobile and embedded vision applications. They are based on a streamlined architecture that uses depthwise separable convolutions to build light weight deep neural networks. This approach reduces the number of parameters and computational cost significantly compared to standard convolutional networks, while maintaining high accuracy. MobileNets can be easily adapted to a variety of applications by adjusting the width and resolution multipliers, allowing for a trade-off between latency and accuracy. The models achieve state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks, demonstrating their effectiveness for mobile vision tasks.

title: BreastGAN: artificial intelligence-enabled breast augmentation simulation
author: Chartier, Christian and Watt, Ayden and Lin, Owen and Chandawarkar, Akash and Lee, James and Hall-Findlay, Elizabeth
abstract: Abstract  Background: Breast augmentation is one of the most common cosmetic surgical procedures performed worldwide. Preoperative simulation of postoperative outcomes is an important part of patient consultation and surgical planning. Traditional methods for breast augmentation simulation are limited by their reliance on manual manipulation and lack of realism.  Objectives: This study aims to develop and evaluate BreastGAN, an artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled breast augmentation simulation tool that uses generative adversarial networks (GANs) to generate realistic postoperative breast images from preoperative photographs.  Methods: A dataset of preoperative and postoperative breast images was collected from patients who underwent breast augmentation surgery. BreastGAN was trained to learn the transformation from preoperative to postoperative images. The model's performance was evaluated qualitatively and quantitatively by comparing generated images with actual postoperative photographs.  Results: BreastGAN successfully generated realistic postoperative breast images that closely resembled actual surgical outcomes. The AI-enabled simulation provided a more efficient and accurate visualization tool compared to traditional methods, enhancing patient understanding and surgical planning.  Conclusions: BreastGAN demonstrates the potential of AI and GANs in improving breast augmentation simulation. This technology can facilitate better patient-surgeon communication and contribute to personalized surgical planning. Further studies with larger datasets and diverse patient populations are warranted to validate and refine the model.

title: Vggface2: A dataset for recognising faces across pose and age
author: Cao, Qiong and Shen, Li and Xie, Weidi and Parkhi, Omkar M and Zisserman, Andrew
abstract: VGGFace2 is a large-scale face recognition dataset. It contains 3.31 million images of 9,131 subjects, with an average of 362.6 images per subject. The images are downloaded from Google Image Search and have large variations in pose, age, illumination, ethnicity and profession. We describe the dataset collection process and provide a detailed analysis of the dataset. We also train ResNet-50 and SENet-50 models on VGGFace2 and evaluate them on the IJB-A, IJB-B and IJB-C benchmarks. Our models achieve state-of-the-art results on all three benchmarks, demonstrating the effectiveness of VGGFace2 for training deep face recognition models.

title: Analysis of surgical outcome after upper eyelid surgery by computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection
author: Bah{\c{c}}eci {\c{S}}im{\c{s}}ek, {\.I}lke and {\c{S}}irolu, Can
journal: Graefe's Archive for Clinical and Experimental Ophthalmology
abstract: Purpose: To analyze the surgical outcome after upper eyelid surgery by a computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection. Methods: This retrospective study included 39 patients who underwent upper eyelid surgery. Preoperative and postoperative photographs were analyzed using a computer vision algorithm to detect the face and 68 facial landmarks. The margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) and palpebral fissure height (PFH) were calculated automatically. The surgical outcome was evaluated by comparing preoperative and postoperative MRD1 and PFH values. Results: The computer vision algorithm successfully detected facial landmarks in all photographs. The mean MRD1 increased significantly from 1.2 ± 0.8 mm preoperatively to 3.5 ± 0.9 mm postoperatively (p < 0.001). The mean PFH also increased significantly from 6.8 ± 1.2 mm to 9.5 ± 1.3 mm (p < 0.001). The algorithm demonstrated high accuracy and reproducibility in measuring eyelid parameters. Conclusion: The computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection is a reliable and objective tool for analyzing surgical outcomes after upper eyelid surgery. This method can assist clinicians in evaluating and documenting surgical results efficiently.

title: Efficientnet: Rethinking model scaling for convolutional neural networks
author: Tan, Mingxing and Le, Quoc
abstract: Convolutional neural networks (ConvNets) are commonly developed at a fixed resource budget, and then scaled up for better accuracy if more resources are available. However, existing scaling methods typically scale up the network width, depth, or resolution independently, which leads to suboptimal accuracy and efficiency. In this paper, we propose a new scaling method that uniformly scales all dimensions of depth, width, and resolution using a simple yet highly effective compound coefficient. Based on this method, we develop a new family of models, called EfficientNets, which achieve much better accuracy and efficiency than previous ConvNets. Our EfficientNet-B7 achieves state-of-the-art 84.3% top-1 accuracy on ImageNet, while being 8.4× smaller and 6.1× faster on inference than the best existing ConvNet. Our models also transfer well to other datasets and tasks. The code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/tensorflow/tpu/tree/master/models/official/efficientnet.

title: Regression Guided by Relative Ranking Using Convolutional Neural Network (R3CNN) for Facial Beauty Prediction
author: Lin, Luojun and Liang, Lingyu and Jin, Lianwen
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) is a challenging task due to the subjective nature of beauty and the lack of large-scale labeled datasets. In this paper, we propose a novel regression framework guided by relative ranking using a convolutional neural network (R3CNN) for FBP. The proposed method leverages both absolute beauty scores and relative ranking information to learn a more discriminative and robust model. Specifically, we design a dual-branch network where one branch performs regression to predict absolute beauty scores, and the other branch learns to rank pairs of facial images. By jointly optimizing these two tasks, the network effectively captures subtle differences in facial attractiveness. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that R3CNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and generalization ability. Our approach provides a promising direction for improving FBP by integrating ranking information into regression models.

title: Regenerative medicine approach to reconstruction of the equine upper airway
author: Grevemeyer B.; Bogdanovic L.; Canton S.; St. Jean G.; Cercone M.; Ducharme N.G.; Brown B.N.
abstract: Regenerative medicine offers promising new approaches for the reconstruction of the equine upper airway, which is often compromised by trauma, infection, or congenital defects. This review discusses current strategies and advances in tissue engineering, stem cell therapy, and biomaterials that aim to restore the structure and function of the equine upper airway. Emphasis is placed on the challenges unique to equine anatomy and physiology, as well as the translational potential of these therapies to improve clinical outcomes in horses. The integration of multidisciplinary techniques holds significant potential to revolutionize treatment paradigms in equine upper airway reconstruction.

title: Machine learning, deep learning, artificial intelligence and aesthetic plastic surgery: a qualitative systematic review
author: Nogueira, Raquel and Eguchi, Marina and Kasmirski, Julia and de Lima, Bruno Veronez and Dimatos, Dimitri Cardoso and Lima, Diego L and Glatter, Robert and Tran, David L and Piccinini, Pedro Salomao
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and deep learning (DL) are rapidly evolving fields that have the potential to revolutionize aesthetic plastic surgery. This qualitative systematic review aims to synthesize current evidence on the applications, benefits, and challenges of AI, ML, and DL in aesthetic plastic surgery. A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify relevant studies. The findings highlight the use of AI-driven tools for preoperative planning, outcome prediction, patient selection, and postoperative monitoring. Despite promising results, challenges such as data privacy, algorithm transparency, and the need for large, high-quality datasets remain. The integration of AI technologies in aesthetic plastic surgery holds significant promise for enhancing surgical precision, patient satisfaction, and clinical outcomes, but further research and ethical considerations are essential for their safe and effective implementation.

title: Evaluation of gel spun silk-based biomaterials in a murine model of bladder augmentation
author: Mauney J.R.; Cannon G.M.; Lovett M.L.; Gong E.M.; Di Vizio D.; Gomez P.; Kaplan D.L.; Adam R.M.; Estrada C.R.
abstract: Bladder augmentation is a surgical procedure used to increase bladder capacity and reduce bladder pressure in patients with congenital or acquired bladder diseases. Current clinical approaches use gastrointestinal segments for bladder reconstruction, but these are associated with significant complications. Tissue engineering offers a promising alternative, and silk fibroin-based biomaterials have shown potential due to their biocompatibility and mechanical properties. In this study, we evaluated gel spun silk-based scaffolds for bladder augmentation in a murine model. The scaffolds were implanted into bladder defects, and tissue regeneration was assessed over time. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses demonstrated the formation of smooth muscle and urothelial layers, as well as neovascularization within the scaffold. Functional assessments indicated improved bladder capacity and compliance. These findings suggest that gel spun silk-based biomaterials support bladder tissue regeneration and may serve as a viable scaffold for bladder augmentation.

title: Keratin films for ocular surface reconstruction: Evaluation of biocompatibility in an in-vivo model
author: Borrelli M.; Joepen N.; Reichl S.; Finis D.; Schoppe M.; Geerling G.; Schrader S.
abstract: The development of biomaterials for ocular surface reconstruction is a challenging task due to the complex structure and function of the cornea. In this study, we evaluated the biocompatibility of keratin films derived from human hair as a potential scaffold for ocular surface reconstruction. Keratin films were fabricated and characterized for their physical and chemical properties. In vivo biocompatibility was assessed by implanting the films onto the ocular surface of a rabbit model. Clinical observations, histological analysis, and immunohistochemical staining were performed to evaluate the inflammatory response, epithelialization, and integration of the films with the host tissue. The results demonstrated that keratin films were well tolerated, promoted epithelial cell adhesion and proliferation, and supported corneal tissue regeneration without eliciting significant inflammation. These findings suggest that keratin films have promising potential as a biocompatible scaffold for ocular surface reconstruction applications.

title: Plastic surgery: A new dimension to face recognition
author: Singh, Richa and Vatsa, Mayank and Bhatt, Himanshu S and Bharadwaj, Samarth and Noore, Afzel and Nooreyezdan, Shahin S
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Plastic surgery is becoming increasingly popular and has a significant impact on face recognition systems. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effects of various plastic surgery procedures on face recognition performance. We analyze the challenges posed by surgical alterations and propose a novel approach to improve recognition accuracy in the presence of such changes. Experimental results on a newly created plastic surgery face database demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, highlighting the need for developing robust face recognition algorithms that can handle post-surgical facial variations.

title: Data-based prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery: clinical assessment of new simulation software
author: Abe, N and Kuroda, S and Furutani, M and Tanaka, E
journal: International journal of oral and maxillofacial surgery
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery is essential for treatment planning and patient communication. This study aimed to clinically assess the accuracy of a new simulation software for predicting soft tissue changes following orthognathic surgery. Twenty patients undergoing bimaxillary surgery were included. Pre- and postoperative three-dimensional facial scans were obtained, and soft tissue changes were predicted using the software based on the planned skeletal movements. The predicted soft tissue outcomes were compared with the actual postoperative results using quantitative and qualitative analyses. The software demonstrated good accuracy in predicting soft tissue changes, particularly in the midface and lower face regions, with mean discrepancies within clinically acceptable limits. However, some limitations were noted in areas with complex soft tissue dynamics. The new simulation software shows promise as a valuable tool for surgical planning and patient education, though further refinement and validation are recommended.

title: Interobserver agreement and consensus over the esthetic evaluation of conservative treatment for breast cancer
author: Cardoso, Maria Joao and Cardoso, Jaime and Santos, Ana Cristina and Barros, Henrique and de Oliveira, Manuel Cardoso
abstract: Background: The esthetic outcome of breast-conserving treatment (BCT) is an important parameter in the evaluation of treatment results. However, the esthetic evaluation is subjective and may vary between observers. The aim of this study was to assess the interobserver agreement and consensus over the esthetic evaluation of BCT.  Methods: Thirty patients treated with BCT were evaluated by 10 observers (breast surgeons, radiation oncologists, and plastic surgeons). The esthetic outcome was scored on a 4-point scale (excellent, good, fair, poor) based on standardized photographs. Interobserver agreement was assessed using kappa statistics. Consensus was reached through a group discussion and re-evaluation.  Results: The overall interobserver agreement was moderate (kappa = 0.48). Agreement was higher among plastic surgeons (kappa = 0.56) compared to breast surgeons (kappa = 0.44) and radiation oncologists (kappa = 0.42). After consensus discussion, the agreement improved significantly (kappa = 0.68).  Conclusions: Esthetic evaluation of BCT shows moderate interobserver agreement, which can be improved by consensus discussions. Standardized evaluation protocols and training may enhance reliability in esthetic assessments.

title: Multi-kernel graph embedding for detection, Gleason grading of prostate cancer via MRI/MRS
author: Tiwari P.; Kurhanewicz J.; Madabhushi A.
abstract: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men and the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) have shown promise for noninvasive detection and characterization of prostate cancer. However, the interpretation of MRI/MRS data is challenging due to the complex and heterogeneous nature of prostate cancer. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-kernel graph embedding (MKGE) framework for the detection and Gleason grading of prostate cancer using MRI/MRS data. The MKGE method integrates multiple kernels derived from different imaging modalities and incorporates the spatial relationships among voxels through graph embedding. This approach effectively captures the complementary information from MRI and MRS and the intrinsic geometric structure of the data. Experimental results on a clinical dataset demonstrate that the proposed MKGE method outperforms traditional single-kernel and feature-based methods in both cancer detection and Gleason grading, indicating its potential for improving prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: Differences in tibial rotation during walking in ACL reconstructed and healthy contralateral knees
author: Scanlan S.F.; Chaudhari A.M.W.; Dyrby C.O.; Andriacchi T.P.
abstract: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury is a common knee injury that often results in altered knee kinematics. This study aimed to investigate differences in tibial rotation during walking between ACL reconstructed knees and healthy contralateral knees. Using a three-dimensional motion analysis system, tibial rotation was measured in 20 subjects with unilateral ACL reconstruction during level walking. The results showed that the ACL reconstructed knees exhibited significantly greater internal tibial rotation during the stance phase of walking compared to the healthy contralateral knees. These findings suggest that ACL reconstruction may not fully restore normal tibial rotational kinematics during gait, which could have implications for joint loading and the development of osteoarthritis.

title: PtosisDiffusion: a training-free workflow for precisely predicting post-operative appearance in blepharoptosis patients based on diffusion models
author: Huang, Shenyu and Xie, Jiajun and Yang, Boyuan and Gao, Qi and Ye, Juan
journal: Frontiers in Cell and Developmental Biology
abstract: PtosisDiffusion is a training-free workflow designed to precisely predict post-operative appearance in blepharoptosis patients using diffusion models. This approach leverages the capabilities of diffusion models to generate high-fidelity images that simulate surgical outcomes without the need for extensive training data. By integrating clinical parameters and pre-operative images, PtosisDiffusion provides surgeons and patients with a reliable visualization tool to anticipate post-surgical results, thereby enhancing pre-operative planning and patient communication. The method demonstrates significant potential in improving surgical precision and patient satisfaction in blepharoptosis treatment.

title: Very deep convolutional networks for large-scale image recognition
author: Simonyan, Karen and Zisserman, Andrew
abstract: We investigate the effect of the convolutional network depth on its accuracy in the large-scale image recognition setting. Our main contribution is a thorough evaluation of networks of increasing depth using an architecture with very small (3×3) convolution filters, which shows that a significant improvement on the prior-art configurations can be achieved by pushing the depth to 16–19 weight layers. These findings were the basis of our ImageNet Challenge 2014 submission, where our team secured the first and the second places in the localisation and classification tracks respectively. We also show that our representations generalise well to other datasets, where they achieve state-of-the-art results.

title: A decade survey of content based image retrieval using deep learning
author: Dubey, Shiv Ram
journal: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Content-based image retrieval (CBIR) is a fundamental and challenging problem in computer vision and pattern recognition. With the rapid development of deep learning, CBIR has witnessed significant progress in recent years. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of deep learning-based CBIR methods over the past decade. We first introduce the background and motivation of CBIR and then review the representative deep learning architectures and techniques applied to CBIR, including convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, generative adversarial networks, and attention mechanisms. We also discuss various feature extraction, feature aggregation, and similarity measurement strategies. Furthermore, we analyze the strengths and limitations of existing methods and highlight several benchmark datasets and evaluation metrics commonly used in CBIR research. Finally, we identify open challenges and potential future research directions to inspire further advancements in deep learning-based CBIR.

title: A Computer-based Surgery Planning and Simulation for the Prediction of 3D Postoperative Facial Soft Tissue using Finite Element Analysis
author: Obaidellah, Unaizah Hanum and Selvanathan, N
abstract: This paper presents a computer-based surgery planning and simulation system for predicting three-dimensional (3D) postoperative facial soft tissue changes using finite element analysis (FEA). The system integrates patient-specific anatomical data obtained from medical imaging with biomechanical modeling to simulate the effects of surgical interventions on facial soft tissues. By constructing a finite element model of the facial soft tissue and underlying bone structures, the system allows surgeons to visualize and evaluate potential surgical outcomes preoperatively. The approach aims to improve surgical planning accuracy and patient communication by providing realistic predictions of postoperative facial appearance. Validation results demonstrate the system's capability to predict soft tissue deformations with clinically acceptable accuracy, highlighting its potential as a valuable tool in maxillofacial surgery.
